section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The Food Supplement Program, formerly known as the Food Stamp Program, provides nutrition assistance to help eligible low-income households buy the food they need for good health.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

"Adjustment" means a debit or credit transaction applied to the recipient's electronic benefit transfer account to correct a system error or an out-of-balance condition identified in the settlement process.
"Administrative error (AE)" means an error caused by the local department's action or failure to act.
"Allotment" means the total value of benefits a household is authorized to receive during each month or other time period.
"Applicant" means an individual for whom assistance has been requested, or the individual's authorized representative.

"Authorized representative" means an adult nonhousehold member who has been designated in writing by the head of household, the spouse of the head of household, or other responsible member of the household to act on behalf of the household.
"Disabled" means an individual who:

Receives Supplemental Security Income benefits or other federal or State-administered payments when eligibility to receive the benefits is based upon the disability or blindness criteria of the Social Security Act;
Is a veteran:
With a service-connected or non-service-connected disability pension rated or paid as total, or
Whom the Veterans Administration considers to be in need of regular aid and attendance, or to be permanently housebound;
Is a surviving spouse of a veteran and considered by the Veterans Administration to be in need of aid and attendance, or to be permanently housebound;
Is a surviving child of a veteran and considered by the Veterans Administration to be permanently incapable of self-support;

Is a surviving spouse or child of a veteran and entitled to compensation for the veteran's service-connected death or pension benefits for a non-service-connected death when the spouse or child has a disability considered permanent;
Is receiving a disability retirement benefit from a government agency because of a disability considered permanent under the Social Security Act;
Is receiving a railroad retirement disability annuity which meets Social Security disability criteria and is determined by the Railroad Retirement Board to qualify for Medicare;
Is receiving interim assistance benefits pending receipt of Supplemental Security Income; or
Is receiving disability-related federal medical assistance.
"Elderly" means an individual who is 60 years old or older.

"Electronic benefit transfer (EBT)" means an online computer-based system in which benefits are stored at a central computer database and benefit authorization is received through a point-of-sale terminal.
"Eligible food" means:
Any food or food product intended for human consumption except alcoholic beverages, tobacco, and hot foods and hot food products prepared for immediate consumption;
Seeds and plants to grow foods for the personal consumption of eligible households;
Meals prepared and delivered by an authorized meal delivery service to households eligible to purchase delivered meals;
Meals served by an authorized communal dining facility for the elderly, or Supplemental Security Income households, to households eligible to use Program benefits for communal dining;
Meals prepared and served by:
A group living arrangement facility to eligible residents who are blind or disabled as defined in Â§B(6) of this regulation, or
A shelter for battered women and children to its eligible residents;
Meals prepared for and served by an authorized public or private nonprofit establishment approved by the State or local agency that feeds individuals who are homeless; and
Meals prepared by a restaurant that contracts with the State to serve meals at low or reduced prices to homeless individuals.
"Head of household" means a household member designated by the household or by the local department to act on behalf of the household.
"Homeless individual" means an individual:
Without a fixed and regular nighttime residence; or
Whose primary nighttime residence is a:
Supervised shelter designed to provide temporary accommodations,
Halfway house or similar institution,
Temporary accommodation, not to exceed 90 days, in the residence of another individual, or
Place not designed for or ordinarily used as a regular sleeping accommodation for human beings, such as a hallway, bus station, lobby, or similar place.
"Homeless meal provider" means a public or private nonprofit soup kitchen, temporary shelter, or similar establishment that feeds homeless individuals.
"Inadvertent household error (IHE)" means an error caused by a misunderstanding or unintended mistake on the part of the household, as determined by the local department.
"Initial month" means:
The first month for which an allotment is issued following any period during which the household was not certified for participation, provided the household does not have an application pending; or

In the case of a migrant or seasonal farm worker household, the first month for which an allotment is issued to a household that applies to participate following a period of more than 30 days in which the household was not certified for participation.
"Intentional program violation (IPV)" means an intentional:
False or misleading statement, or misrepresentation, concealment, or withholding of facts; or
Act that constitutes a violation of:
The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008;
The Program regulations; or
Any State statute or regulation relating to the use, presentation, transfer, acquisition, receipt, or possession of food stamp benefits or electronic benefits transfer (EBT) cards.
"Local department" means a department of social services in a county or Baltimore City and the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services.
"Local department area" means the jurisdiction served by the local department.
âMaryland Senior Nutrition Assistance Program (MSNAP)â means the combined application demonstration project approved by the United States Department of Agriculture Food and Nutrition Service.
"Meal services" means a nonprofit meal delivery service, such as Meals on Wheels, or a communal dining arrangement.
"Program" means:
Maryland's Food Supplement Program (FSP); or
The Federal Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), formerly the Food Stamp Program.
"Public assistance (PA)" means any of the following programs:
Temporary Cash Assistance (TCA) as described in COMAR 07.03.03;
Temporary Disability Assistance Program (TDAP) as described in COMAR 07.03.05; or
Public Assistance to Adults (PAA) as described in COMAR 07.03.07.
"Qualified alien" means an individual who is not a citizen of the United States who:
Is lawfully admitted for permanent residence under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA);
Is admitted to the United States as a refugee under Â§207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
Is granted asylum under Â§208 of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
Has had deportation or removal withheld under Â§243(h) or 241(b)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
Has been granted status as a Cuban or Haitian entrant as defined in Â§501(e) of the Refugee Education Assistance Act of 1980;
Is paroled into the United States under Â§212(d)(5) of the Immigration and Nationality Act for a period of at least 1 year;
Is granted conditional entry pursuant to Â§203(a)(7) of the Immigration and Nationality Act as in effect before April 1, 1980; or
Is a battered spouse, battered child, or parent or child of a battered individual.
"Service Access and Information Link (SAIL)" means the Maryland web-based online application for Program benefits.
"Shelter for battered women and children" means a facility operated in Maryland as a safe accommodation for battered women and children.

"Sponsor" means an individual who executed an affidavit of support or similar agreement on behalf of an immigrant as a condition of the immigrant's entry or admission into the United States as a permanent resident.
"Spouse" refers to either of two individuals who:
Would be defined as married to each other under applicable State law; or
Are living together and are holding themselves out to the community as husband and wife by representing themselves as husband and wife to relatives, friends, neighbors, or trades people.
"Supplemental Security Income (SSI)" means a monthly cash payment by the Social Security Administration to an aged, blind, or disabled individual.
System Error.
"System error" means an error resulting from a malfunction at any point in the redemption process including:
From the system host computer,
To the switch,
To the third-party processors,
To a store's host computer, or
Point of service (POS) terminal.
"System error" may not include human errors, such as those that may result in incorrect postings or incorrect entries at the POS.
"Thrifty Food Plan" means the cost of the diet, as determined by the Department of Agriculture and adjusted for family size, required to feed a family of four individuals consisting of a:
Man and a woman, 20 through 50 years old;
Child, 6 through 8 years old; and
Child, 9 through 11 years old.
"Trafficking" means the:
Buying or selling of Program benefits for cash or consideration other than eligible food; or
Exchange of firearms, ammunition, explosives, or controlled substances, as defined in 21 U.S.C. Â§802, for Program benefits.
"United States non-citizen national" means an individual:
Born in an outlying possession of the United States on or after the date the United States acquired possession; or
Whose parents are United States non-citizen nationals.
Household Definition. A household may be composed of any of the following individuals or groups of individuals:
An individual living alone;
An individual living with others, but customarily purchasing food and preparing meals for home consumption separate and apart from others;
A group of individuals who live together and customarily purchase food and prepare meals together for home consumption;
An individual who is 60 years old or older, and the spouse of that individual, who:
Is living with others;
Is unable to purchase and prepare meals because the individual suffers from a:
Disability considered permanent under the Social Security Act, or
Non-disease-related, severe, permanent disability; and

Resides with others whose income included under Regulation .30 of this chapter, excluding the income of the disabled individual's spouse, does not exceed 165 percent of the poverty line according to household size as shown in Schedule C of Regulation .45 of this chapter.
Individuals or groups of individuals may not participate as a household in the Program if they are:
Residents of an institution, except as otherwise specified in Regulation .06 of this chapter;
Residents of a commercial boarding house;
Living with others and paying them compensation for meals and lodging except as specified in Regulation .05 of this chapter;
Ineligible household members as described in Regulation .04 of this chapter; or
Strikers as described in Regulation .07 of this chapter.
Special Definition. Nonhousehold member status as described in Â§D of this regulation, or separate household status, may not be granted to:
Parents living with their natural or adopted children, or stepchildren, or children living with these parents, if the children are 21 years old or younger;
A minor child, except for a foster child, who is younger than 18 years old, under the parental control of an adult member of the household; or
A spouse of a member of the household as defined in Regulation .02B of this chapter.
Nonhousehold Members.
Nonhousehold members who are otherwise eligible may participate in the Program as separate households.
The local department may not consider the following individuals residing with a household as household members in determining the household's eligibility or allotment:
A roomer who is an individual to whom a household furnishes lodging, but not meals, for financial compensation;
A live-in attendant who is an individual who resides with a household to provide medical, housekeeping, child care, or other similar personal services; or
Other individuals who share living quarters with the household but who do not customarily purchase food and prepare meals with the household.
The local department:
May not include ineligible household members in the household:
When determining the household's size for assigning a benefit level to the household, or
For comparing the household's monthly income with the income eligibility standards; and
Shall treat the income and resources of an ineligible member in the manner described in Regulation .40 of this chapter.
The following household members are ineligible:
An immigrant who is:
Illegally present in the United States,
On a student, tourist, or visitor visa,
A diplomat, or
Lawfully admitted for permanent residence but who does not satisfy the requirements of Regulation .09 of this chapter;
An individual who:
Fails to provide a Social Security number,
Is disqualified for intentional program violation as described in Regulation .56 of this chapter,
Fails to comply with a work requirement as described in Regulation .21 of this chapter, or
Flees to avoid prosecution, custody, or confinement after conviction for a crime, or attempt to commit a crime, that is a felony, for the period the individual is fleeing;
A student who does not meet the eligibility criteria set forth in Regulation .10 of this chapter;
An able-bodied adult without dependents who does not meet the work requirement as described in Regulation .23 of this chapter; or
Except as described in Â§C of this regulation, an individual who is convicted for an offense after August 22, 1996, which:
Is classified as a felony, and
Has an element of possession, use, or distribution of a controlled substance.
An Individual with a Drug-Related Felony Offense.

An applicant for Program participation who is an individual convicted of a felony offense as described in Â§B(5) of this regulation may receive Program benefits if, for 2 years starting from the date of application, the individual submits to:
Testing for substance abuse as established by the Department; and
Treatment consistent with Article 88A, Â§50A, Annotated Code of Maryland.

If an individual is convicted of a violation of Criminal Law Article, Â§Â§5-602â5-609, Annotated Code of Maryland, or 21 U.S.C. Â§841 (the manufacture or distribution of a controlled dangerous substance or possession with intent to distribute a controlled dangerous substance) while receiving Program benefits, the individual is:
Ineligible for 1 year from the date of the conviction; and
Subject to testing and treatment for substance abuse for a period of 2 years starting from the later of the date when the individual:
Is released from incarceration,
Completes any term of probation, or
Completes any term of parole and mandatory supervision.
An individual required to be included in the household as described in Regulation .03C of this chapter is not considered a boarder.
A boarder is an individual residing with others and paying them reasonable compensation for lodging and meals.
Reasonable Compensation for Meals.
To determine if an individual is paying reasonable compensation for meals in making a determination of boarder status, the boarder's monthly payment for meals shall be either of the following:
For more than two meals a day, an amount which equals or exceeds the Thrifty Food Plan shown in Schedule D of Regulation .45 of this chapter, for the appropriate size of the boarder household; or
For two meals or less per day, an amount that equals or exceeds 2/3 of the Thrifty Food Plan for the appropriate size of the boarder household.
The amount of the payment that a boarder gives to a household shall be treated as self- employment income to the household.
A foster care individual is considered a boarder.
A boarder is ineligible to participate in the Program as a separate household.
A Boarder As a Participating Household Member.
An individual who is furnished meals but pays compensation of less than a reasonable amount to the household for the meals is considered a member of the household providing the meals.
The household that includes a boarder may participate in the Program if the household meets all the eligibility requirements for Program participation.
A boarder may participate as a member of the household if the boarder receives food stamp services at the household's request.
The local department may not consider as available to the household any of the income or resources of individuals:
Determined to be boarders; and
Who are not members of the household providing the boarder with meals as described in Â§E of this regulation.
A resident of an institution may not participate in the Program, except for:
A resident of federally subsidized housing for the elderly;
A drug addict or alcoholic regularly participating in a drug or alcohol treatment and rehabilitation program as described in Â§D of this regulation;
An individual who is blind or disabled, as defined in Regulation .02B of this chapter, and who is in a group living arrangement as described in Â§C of this regulation;
An individual in a shelter for battered women and children operated by a nonprofit public or private agency as described in Â§E of this regulation; or
A resident of a public or private nonprofit shelter for the homeless as described in Â§F of this regulation.
An individual is considered a resident of an institution when the institution:
Provides over 50 percent of three meals daily as part of the institution's normal services; and
Has not been authorized to accept Program benefits.
Residents of Group Living Arrangements.
A group living arrangement is a public or private nonprofit residential setting that:
Serves no more than 16 residents; and
Is certified by the Department or the Maryland Department of Health under Â§1616(e) of the Social Security Act or comparable standards.
A resident who is blind or disabled as defined in Regulation .02B of this chapter is eligible for Program benefits.
Residents may apply for Program benefits:
On their own; or
Through an authorized representative.
Residents of Drug and Alcoholic Treatment Centers.

Drug addicts or alcoholics, and their children, who regularly participate in a residential publicly operated or private nonprofit drug or alcoholic treatment program may apply to participate in the Program.
The local department shall certify residents of drug and alcoholic treatment centers through an authorized representative who is an employee of the center.
Shelters for Battered Women and Children.
A shelter resident who left a certified household containing the abuser may apply for and be certified for the Program as a separate household.
A local department shall:

Certify shelter residents who apply as separate households on the basis of the resident's income, resources, and the expenses for which the resident is responsible without regard to the income and resources of the former household; and
Consider jointly held resources as inaccessible.
Residents of Public or Private Nonprofit Shelters for the Homeless.
An individual who resides in a shelter for the homeless is entitled to apply for and, if eligible, receive Program benefits.
The homeless shelter may not require a resident of the homeless shelter to surrender Program benefits to the shelter.
The use of Program benefits to purchase prepared meals from public or private nonprofit homeless meal providers shall be voluntary.
A striker is an individual who participates in a strike or a concerted stoppage of work or interruption of operations by employees.
If a household member is a striker, the household is ineligible for benefits unless the household was eligible for benefits:
On the day before the strike; and
At the time of application.
For purposes of the Program, an individual is not a striker if the:
Individual is exempt from work registration requirements of the Program for an exemption other than employment;
Employer closed the individual's work place to resist demands of employees;
Individual, who is not on strike, is unable to work as a result of striking employees; or
Individual is an employee who:
Is not a part of the bargaining unit on strike, and
Does not want to cross the picket line due to fear of personal injury.

If the household was eligible the day before the strike began and was otherwise eligible at the time of application, it cannot receive an increased allotment due to decreased income as a result of the strike.
The household shall provide:
The address of the household's dwelling; and
Verification that the household resides in the political subdivision served by the local department where the household is applying.
A homeless applicant who is present in the local department area is a resident of that area for Program purposes.
An individual may not participate in more than one household or local department area in any given month unless the individual:
Is a resident of a shelter for battered women and children as described in Regulation .06E of this chapter; and
Was a member of the same household as the individual who had committed the abuse.
An individual may not participate in the Program unless the individual is:
A United States citizen;
A United States non-citizen national as defined in Regulation .02B of this chapter;

A Native American born in Canada who possesses at least 50 percent of blood of the Native American race to whom the provisions of Immigration and Nationality Act Â§289 apply as defined in 8 U.S.C. Â§1359 or a member of an Indian tribe as defined in 25 U.S.C. Â§450(e);
Lawfully residing in the United States, and:
Was a member of a Hmong or Highland Lao tribe at the time the tribe assisted the U.S. armed forces during the Vietnam War;
Is the spouse or surviving spouse of an individual described in Â§A(4)(a) of this regulation; or
Is an unmarried biological or legally adopted dependent child of an individual described in Â§A(4)(a) of this regulation if the child is:
17 years old or younger,
21 years old or younger and a full time student, or
Disabled and 18 years old or older if the child was disabled and dependent on the individual described in Â§A(4)(a) of this regulation when the child was younger than 18 years old; or
Both a qualified alien as defined in Regulation .02B of this chapter and an eligible immigrant as described in Â§Â§BâF of this regulation.
Time Limited Eligibility. An immigrant is an eligible immigrant if the individual has:
Been admitted to the United States as a refugee under Â§207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
Been granted asylum under Â§208 of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
Had the immigrant's deportation or removal withheld under Â§243(h) or Â§241(b)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
Been granted status as a Cuban and Haitian entrant as defined in Â§501(e) of the Refugee Education Assistance Act of 1980;
Been admitted to the United States as an Amerasian immigrant under 8 U.S.C. Â§1612(a)(2)(A); or

Been certified by the United States Department of Health and Human Services Office of Refugee Resettlement as a victim of a severe form of trafficking in persons in accordance with Public Law 106-386 Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000.
Work Quarters. An immigrant who is lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence under the Immigration and Nationality Act is eligible if the individual:
Has worked 40 qualifying quarters of coverage as defined under Title II of the Social Security Act; or
Can be credited with the qualifying quarters.
Military Connection. An immigrant who is a qualified alien is eligible if the individual is:

An honorably discharged veteran of the U.S. armed forces who fulfills the minimum active duty service requirements of 38 U.S.C. Â§5303A(d), including an individual who died in active military, naval, or air service;
On active military duty, other than active duty for training in the U.S. armed forces;
The spouse or unmarried dependent child of an individual described in Â§D(1) or (2) of this regulation if the:
Marriage fulfilled the requirements of 38 U.S.C. Â§1304; and
Spouse has not remarried; or
An unmarried biological or legally adopted dependent child of an individual described in Â§D(1) or (2) of this regulation if the child is:
17 years old or younger,
21 years old or younger and a full time student, or
Disabled and 18 years old or older if the child was disabled and dependent on the individual described in Â§D(1) or (2) of this regulation when the child was younger than 18 years old.
An immigrant who is a qualified alien and who was lawfully residing in the U.S. on August 22, 1996, is eligible if the individual was born on or before August 22, 1931.
An immigrant who is a qualified alien as defined in Regulation .02B of this chapter is eligible if the individual:
Is disabled as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter;
Has resided in the United States as a qualified alien for 5 years or more, beginning on the date of the immigrant's entry into the United States; or
Is a child younger than 18 years old.
While waiting for acceptable verification, an immigrant is ineligible until the household provides acceptable proof, except if the:
Local department has sent a copy of a document furnished by the household to INS for verification;

Applicant or local department has sent a request to the Social Security Administration (SSA) for information about the number of quarters of work as described in Â§C of this regulation, SSA has responded that the individual has fewer than 40 quarters, and the individual provides documentation from SSA that SSA is investigating to see if SSA can credit more work quarters; or
Applicant or local department has submitted a request to a federal agency for proof of information that has a bearing on the individual's immigrant status.

section.heading: Immigrant Sponsored under an Affidavit of Support.

para.text: When an immigrant is sponsored under an affidavit of support Form I-864 or I-864A in accordance with Immigration and Nationality Act Â§213A, the local department shall consider available to the household the monthly income of the sponsor and the sponsor's spouse, if the sponsor's spouse has executed Form I-864 or I-864A in the following manner:

Income considered to be that of the sponsored immigrant is the total monthly earned and unearned income, as described in Regulation .30B and C of this chapter, at the time the household containing the sponsored immigrant member applies for or is recertified for Program participation, reduced by:
A 20 percent earned income amount for that portion of the income determined as earned income of the sponsor and the sponsor's spouse; and

An amount equal to the Program's monthly gross income eligibility limit, as described in Schedule A in Regulation .45 of this chapter, for a household equal in size to the sponsor, the sponsor's spouse, and any other individual who is claimed or could be claimed by the sponsor or the sponsor's spouse as a dependent for federal income tax purposes.
If the immigrant has already reported gross income information on the sponsor due to another State agency's sponsored immigrant rules, that income amount may be used for Program deeming purposes.

The local department shall consider as income actual money paid to the immigrant by the sponsor and the sponsor's spouse to the extent that this amount exceeds the amount attributed to the immigrant under Â§A(1) of this regulation.
Countable Resources.
The local department shall count the total amount of resources of the sponsor and sponsor's spouse to be that of the immigrant in accordance with Regulation .26 of this chapter, reduced by $1,500.

If the immigrant has already reported total resource information of the sponsor due to TCA's sponsored immigrant rules, the resource amount calculated by TCA as the amount to be attributed to the alien may be used for Program deeming purposes.

If a sponsored immigrant can demonstrate that the immigrant's sponsor sponsors other immigrants, then the income and resources as described in Â§Â§AâC of this regulation shall be divided by the number of those immigrants.
Exempt Immigrants. The provisions of Â§Â§AâC of this regulation do not apply to an immigrant who:
Is participating in the Program as a member of a sponsor's household;
Is sponsored by an organization or group instead of an individual;
Is not required to have a sponsor under the Immigration and Nationality Act, such as, but not limited to being:
A refugee;
A parolee;
An individual granted asylum; or
A Cuban or Haitian entrant;
Is a battered spouse or child, with the exemption lasting 12 months, if:

The individual has been battered or subjected to extreme cruelty in the United States by the individual's spouse or parents or by another family member residing in the household who was allowed to commit the act;
The battery or cruelty has a substantial connection to the need for benefits; and
The spouse or child subjected to the cruelty is not living with the individual who committed the acts; or

Would be without food or shelter because the sum of the eligible sponsored immigrant's household's own income, the cash contribution of the sponsor and others, and the value of any in-kind assistance the sponsor and others provide does not exceed the gross income amount shown in Schedule A in Regulation .45 of this chapter for the household size.
Sponsored Immigrant Responsibility. During the period the immigrant is subject to Â§Â§AâC of this regulation, the immigrant is responsible for:

Obtaining the cooperation of the immigrant's sponsor for providing the local department, at the time of application and at the time of recertification, with the information and documentation necessary to calculate countable income and resources in accordance with Â§Â§AâC of this regulation; and
Providing the names, or other identifying factors, of other immigrants for whom the immigrant's sponsor has signed an affidavit of support.
Awaiting Verification.
Until a sponsored immigrant provides information or verification necessary to calculate income and resources as described in Â§Â§AâC of this regulation:
The sponsored immigrant is ineligible; and
The local department:
Shall determine the eligibility and benefit level of any remaining household members;
Shall consider available to the remaining household members the income and resources of the sponsored immigrant; and
May not include the deemed income and resources of the immigrant's sponsor or the sponsor's spouse.

If the sponsored immigrant refuses to cooperate in providing information or verification of income and resources as described in Â§Â§AâC of this regulation, the other adult members of the immigrant's household shall provide the information or verification.
The sponsor's support obligation terminates when the:
Sponsored immigrant becomes a citizen of the United States;

Sponsored immigrant has worked, or can be credited with 40 qualifying quarters of work, except that the sponsored immigrant is not credited with any quarter beginning after December 31, 1996, during which the immigrant receives a federal means-tested benefit;
Sponsored immigrant ceases to hold the status of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent status and has departed the United States;
Sponsored immigrant dies; or
Sponsor dies.
Except as specified in Â§D of this regulation, a student is ineligible to participate in the Program.
A student is an individual who is:
18 years old or older but younger than 50 years old;
Physically and mentally fit; and
Enrolled at least half time in an institution of higher education.
An individual is not considered a student for purposes of the Program if the individual:
Does not meet the criteria described in Â§B of this regulation; or
Is participating in on-the-job training programs.
A student may be eligible to participate in the Program if the student meets at least one of the following requirements:

Is employed and paid for a minimum of 20 hours per week or, if self-employed, is employed for a minimum of 20 hours per week, and receives weekly earnings at least equal to the federal minimum hourly wage as published by the United States Department of Labor, multiplied by 20 hours;
Participates in a State or federally financed work study program during the regular school year;
Is responsible for the care of a dependent household member younger than 6 years old;

Is responsible for the care of a dependent household member who is 6 years old or older but is younger than 12 years old, if the local department has determined that adequate child care is not available;
Is receiving benefits from the Temporary Cash Assistance Program;
Participates in a program at an institution of higher education under:
The Workforce Investment Act of 1998,
The Food Stamp Employment and Training Program, or
Another employment or training program operated by the State or a local government if the program is equivalent to an acceptable Food Stamp Employment and Training Program; or

Is a single parent enrolled full-time in an institution of higher education and responsible for the care of a dependent child younger than 12 years old or, if the parent is not in the household, is a single individual enrolled full time who has parental control over the child.
Work Study Requirement.
A student meets the work study requirement as described in Â§D(2) of this regulation if:
The student is approved for the work study program at the time of application for food stamps;
The work study program is approved for the school term; and
The student anticipates working during the school term.
When a student meets the work study requirement, the exemption begins the month in which the school term begins or the month in which the work study is approved, whichever is later.
Once the exemption begins, the exemption continues until:
The end of the month in which the school term ends; or
It becomes known that the student has refused an assignment.
Unless the student is participating in the work study program during the break, the exemption may not continue between school terms when there is a break of a full month or longer.

The enrollment status of a student begins on the first day of the school term of the institution of higher education and continues through normal periods of class attendance, vacation, and recess, unless the student:
Graduates;
Is suspended or expelled;
Drops out; or
Does not intend to register for the next normal school term.
The local department may not consider the income and resources of an ineligible student living with a household in determining eligibility or level of benefits of the household.
To be eligible for the Program the household shall:
Provide a Social Security number for each member; or
Show documentary evidence that each member has applied for a number.
The local department shall verify the number through the Social Security Administration.
Social Security Number for a Newborn.

If the household cannot provide or apply for a Social Security number for a newborn immediately after the baby's birth, the household shall provide a Social Security number or proof of application the later of:
The next recertification; or
Within 6 months following the month in which the child is born.
The local department shall determine if good cause exists if the household cannot provide the baby's Social Security number at its next recertification or within 6 months following the baby's birth.

When a household is entitled to expedited service, a newborn may participate for up to 6 months following the month of its birth before the household provides the baby's Social Security number or proof of application for its Social Security number.
A household is categorically eligible for Program benefits if all members of the household are receiving or are authorized to receive:
Cash benefits funded in full or in part with federal money under Title IV-A or with State money counted for maintenance of effort purposes under Title IV-A;

Non-cash or in-kind service programs funded in full or in part with federal money under Title IV-A or with State money counted for maintenance of effort purposes under Title IV-A that are designed to further purposes one and two of the Temporary Assistance to Needy Families block grant, as set forth in Public Law 104-193 Â§401;
Temporary Disability Assistance Program (TDAP);
Public Assistance to Adults (PAA); or
SSI benefits.
Categorical eligibility means that the local department shall accept without the verification required in Regulation .20 of this chapter, the following food stamp eligibility factors:
Resource and gross and net income limits;
Social Security number;
Sponsored alien information; and
Residency.
A categorically eligible household is not subject to the income eligibility standards of Regulation .42A and B of this chapter.
A household is not categorically eligible if:
All members of the household are institutionalized in accordance with Regulation .06 of this chapter;
A member is disqualified for an intentional program violation in accordance with Regulation .56 of this chapter; or
The head of household is disqualified for failure to comply with work registration requirements in accordance with Regulations .22 and .24 of this chapter.
The local department may not include an individual as a member of a household otherwise categorically eligible if that individual is:
An ineligible immigrant as described in Regulation .09 of this chapter;
Ineligible under the student provision in Regulation .10 of this chapter;
Institutionalized in a non-exempt facility as defined in Regulation .06 of this chapter; or
Ineligible because of failure to comply with a work requirement as described in Regulations .21 and .24 of this chapter.
An individual who receives zero Public Assistance (PA) as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter or SSI benefits is considered a recipient of a benefit from those programs if the individual is:
Authorized to receive the benefit but has not yet received payment;
Entitled to the benefit but the benefit is suspended or recouped; or
Entitled to the benefit but is not receiving it because the grant is less than the minimum amount.

A household otherwise categorically eligible that has filed a joint PA and FSP application and is denied Program benefits, but is later determined eligible for PA benefits, shall be issued Program benefits using the original application and any other pertinent information occurring after that application.

To determine if a household is eligible for Program benefits due to its status as a PA or SSI household, the local department may postpone the Program eligibility determination for 30 days if the household:
Is not entitled to expedited service; and
Appears to be categorically eligible.
The local department shall postpone denying a potentially categorically eligible household until the 30th day if the household appears to be eligible to receive PA benefits.
Once the PA application is approved, the household is considered categorically eligible unless ineligible under Â§D of this regulation.
If the PA application is denied, the local department:
Shall continue processing the application according to Program regulations; or
May require a new application if the local department does not have enough information to make the eligibility determination.
The local department shall exclude the resources of a household member who receives TCA or SSI.
May not impose special requirements on the household, such as requiring that the head of household rather than another responsible member of the household appear at the local department; and
May designate the head of household if the household does not choose to do so.

section.heading: Filing an Application for the Program.

para.text: The household:

Shall file a Program application by submitting the form to the local department either in person, through an authorized representative, by fax, by mail, through SAIL, or by completing an on-line electronic application in the local department; and
Has the right to file an application form, during office hours, on the same day it contacts the local department.

The local department shall allow an eligible household that completes the initial application process to participate as soon as possible but not later than 30 calendar days following the date that the application was filed.
A household in which all members are recipients of SSI may apply for Program benefits at a Social Security office, if the household:
Has not applied for the Program in the preceding 30 days; and
Does not have an application pending at a local department.
The request for an application may be made:
In person;
By telephone;
By mail; or
By an authorized representative.
Responsibilities of the Applicant. The applicant shall:
Complete the application form as described in this regulation;
Have an interview with a local department representative as described in Regulation .15 of this chapter;
Provide the required verification as described in Regulation .20 of this chapter; and
Complete any required work registration as described in Regulation .21 of this chapter.
A completed application includes:
Required verifications;
Required work registrations; and
The completed and signed application form.
Responsibilities of the Local Department. The local department shall:
Furnish the application form to the applicant on the same day, directly or by mail, when the request is made by telephone or mail;
Advise the applicant that the:
Applicant does not have to be interviewed before filing the application, and
Application form is counted as filed when the form contains the applicant's name and address, and is signed by a responsible member of the household or the household's authorized representative;
Receive the application, date it, and determine if it is complete;
Screen applications to determine if an applicant needs expedited service as described in Regulation .19 of this chapter;
Arrange the appointment for any required face-to-face interview; and
Provide a list of required verifications and assist the household in obtaining the necessary verifications.
When the entire household is also applying for public assistance, the local department shall:
Conduct a single interview at application and recertification, whenever possible; and
Apply the time limits and Program requirements to the FSP part of the application.

The date the application form is received at the local department is the filing date, except that for a household in which all members are recipients of SSI, the application shall be considered filed when the Social Security office receives the application form.
An SSI household that has applied for food stamp benefits at the Social Security office may not be:
Required to see a local department eligibility worker;
Interviewed by the local department;
Contacted by the local department for certification information unless:
The application is improperly completed,
Mandatory verification is missing, or
The local department determines that certain information on the application is questionable; or
Required to appear at the local department before the eligibility determination can be made.
Withdrawing an Application for the Program. The household may withdraw the application at any time before the eligibility determination without prejudice to any subsequent application.
The interview may take place:
When the applicant comes to the local department to request benefits;
When the local department representative visits the applicantâs residence if Â§C of this regulation applies;
When the local department representative meets with the applicant on a date scheduled after the request was received; or
By telephone.
If the applicant fails to keep the appointment for a face-to-face interview or scheduled telephone interview, the applicant is responsible for scheduling another appointment. If the applicant:
Requests a second appointment and is determined eligible, the local department shall issue benefits from the date of application; or
Does not request a second appointment, the local department may deny the application on the 30th day after application.
Scheduling an Interview at Application. The local department shall:
Schedule an interview for all applicant households who are not interviewed on the day the household submits an application; and
Notify each household that misses its interview that the household:
Missed the scheduled interview; and
Is responsible for rescheduling the interview.

The local department shall notify the applicant that the local department shall waive the office interview in favor of a telephone interview or a scheduled home visit on a case-by-case basis for hardship situations, which include but are not limited to:
Transportation difficulties;
Illness;
Care of a household member;
Prolonged severe weather;
Hardship due to residency in a rural area; or
Work or training hours that prevent an in-office interview.
The local department may waive the face-to-face interview in favor of a telephone interview for all households
Interviews may take place by telephone, at the local department, the householdâs residence, or other mutually acceptable location.
If the interview takes place at the household's residence, the local department shall schedule the interview in advance with the household.

section.heading: Notices to Applicants.
section.text: The local department shall provide applicants with one of the following written notices as soon as a determination is made, but not later than 30 days after the filing date:

para.text: A notice of eligibility which shall include:
The benefit level and the certification period,
Any variation in the benefit level based on anticipated changes,
The right to and method for obtaining a fair hearing,
The telephone number and the name of an individual in the local department to call for information or clarification, and
The availability of any legal services;
A notice of denial which shall include the:
Reason for the decision, and
Information listed in Â§A(3)â(5) of this regulation; or
A notice of pending status in accordance with Regulation .18A of this chapter.
Refusal to Cooperate.

The local department shall deny the application for refusal to cooperate if the household refuses to cooperate with the local department in completing the process described in Regulation .14 of this chapter.

To make a determination of refusal to cooperate, the local department shall determine that the household was able to cooperate but demonstrated that it would not take actions that were required to complete the application process.
If there is a question as to whether the household has only failed to cooperate, as opposed to refused to cooperate, the local department may not deny the household on the grounds of refusal.

The local department shall find the household ineligible if it refuses to cooperate in subsequent reviews of its eligibility, including reviews generated by reported changes and applications for recertification.
Once denied or terminated for refusal to cooperate, the household may reapply but may not be determined eligible until it cooperates with the local department.
Quality Control Review.
The local department shall find the household ineligible if it refuses to cooperate in any review of its eligibility as a part of a quality control review.
If a household is terminated for refusal to cooperate with a quality control review, the household may reapply but may not be determined eligible until it cooperates with the quality control review.
Notice of Pending Status.
The local department shall send a notice of pending status to the applicant if the:
Application is not complete; or
Local department does not make a decision on eligibility within 30 days after filing.
If the local department caused the delay, the notice shall include the:
Reason for the delay; and
Any action that the household or the local department must take.
If the household does not complete the application before the end of the 30-day period, the notice shall include:
The action the household is required to take; and
A warning that the local department shall deny the application if it is not completed within 60 days of its filing date.
If the local department failed to schedule the first interview within 30 days of the filing date, the notice shall include:
The date of the appointment;
A list of any verification needed; and
A warning that, if the application is incomplete at the end of the 60-day period after the filing date because of any failure of the household, the local department shall deny the application.
Delay Caused by the Local Department.
If the local department caused a delay in the application process, the local department shall:
Continue to process the application; and
Calculate the benefit from the filing date as described in Regulation .14I of this chapter.
Local department caused delays include, but are not limited to, the local department's failure to:
Offer or provide assistance to the household to complete the application form;
Notify the household with a statement of required verification or to allow the household 10 days after the local department's request for verification;
Explore and attempt to resolve with the household, unclear or incomplete information;
Notify the household that it could reschedule a missed interview; or
Notify the household that:
Certain members are required to register for work, or
The household is allowed 10 days after the notification to register the members.
Delay Caused by the Household.
If the application is completed after the 30th day and before the 60th day due to a delay caused by the household, the benefit calculation is from the date the household takes the required action.
Household caused delays include, but are not limited to, the household's failure to:
Cooperate with the local department in resolving unclear or incomplete information provided at the interview;
Register household members for work;
Provide missing verification; or
Reschedule a missed appointment.
A household shall have expedited service if:
The household has less than $100 in liquid resources and less than $150 in gross monthly income;
The household's combined monthly gross income and liquid resources are less than the household's monthly rent or mortgage and utilities; or
A migrant or seasonal farm worker household has less than $100 in liquid resources and is determined by the local department to be destitute as described in Â§B of this regulation.
Destitute Migrant Households.
To be destitute for Program purposes means the migrant household's only income for the month of application:
Was received before the date of application and was from a terminated source; or
Is from a new source and the household does not expect to receive income of more than $25 from the new source by the 10th calendar day after the date of application.
The eligibility and benefit level for a destitute household is calculated for the month of application considering only income received between the first of the month and the date of application.
Any income from a new source that is anticipated after the date of application is disregarded.
Time Limits for Expedited Service.

The local department shall make Program benefits for a 1 month's allotment available to a household described in Â§A of this regulation by the close of business on the 7th calendar day after the filing date, including weekends or holidays.
Out-of-Office Interviews.
If the local department has waived the office interview for a household entitled to expedited service, the local department shall complete the process within the expedited service time limit.
The local department may not include in the 7-day processing standard the days that the application is in the mail and in the possession of the household.

Late Determination of Expedited Eligibility. If the local department discovers a household's entitlement to expedited service after the screening process required in Regulation .14G(4) of this chapter, the local department shall make benefits available within the time frame described in Â§C(1) of this regulation beginning with the date of discovery.
Special Procedures for Expedited Service. To expedite the certification process, the local department:
Shall verify the applicant's identity through:
Readily available documentary evidence, or
Collateral contact;
Shall make all reasonable efforts to complete required verification as described in Regulation .20C(2)â(12) of this chapter;
May not delay benefits beyond the expedited time frame solely because the eligibility factors as described in Â§D(2) of this regulation have not been verified; and
Shall assign a normal certification period to households that are certified on an expedited basis and have provided all necessary verification.
Postponed Verification.
If a household applies on or before the 15th of the month and verification is postponed:
The local department may:
Certify the household for the month of application only; or
Assign a normal certification period; and
Benefits may not be continued beyond the month of application if verification continues to be postponed.
If a household applies on or after the 16th of the month and verification is postponed:
The local department may:
Certify the household for the month of application and the following month; or
Assign a normal certification period; and
Benefits may not be continued beyond the month following the month of application if verification continues to be postponed.
The local department shall notify the household in writing that no further benefits may be issued until the postponed verification is complete.

Number of Expedited Service Certifications. There is no limit to the number of times a household can be certified under expedited procedures, if before each expedited certification the household either:
Completes the verification requirements that were postponed at the last expedited certification; or
Was certified under normal processing standards since the last expedited certification.
Verification is the use of third-party information or documentation to establish the accuracy of statements on the application.
The local department shall assist the household to obtain the necessary verification.
At initial application, and before certification, the household shall provide verification of the following:
Identity of the applicant, or, when an authorized representative applies, the identity of the applicant and authorized representative;
Gross nonexcludable income as described in Regulation .30 of this chapter;
Immigrant status for an immigrant in the household in accordance with Regulation .09 of this chapter;
Medical expenses as described in Regulation .33 of this chapter, if the household claims allowable medical expenses above $35 per month;
Residency as described in Regulation .08 of this chapter;
Social Security number as described in Regulation .11 of this chapter;
Amount of included resources as described in Regulation .26 of this chapter;
Legal obligation to make child support payments to or for an individual living outside the household and the amount of actual payments as described in Regulation .35 of this chapter;
Household composition, if questionable as described in Â§G of this regulation;
Shelter costs for homeless households claiming shelter expenses that would result in a shelter deduction greater than the homeless allowance;
Hours worked for individuals subject to the work requirement for able-bodied adults without dependents as described in Regulation .23 of this chapter;
Disability if the disability determination affects the household's eligibility or benefit level; and
All other factors of eligibility that are questionable as described in Â§G of this regulation and affect the household's eligibility and benefit level.
Optional Verification.
The Department may require verification of any other factor that affects eligibility or benefit level.
The verification:
May be required Statewide or in a local department area; and
May not be imposed on a selective case-by-case basis.

If a local department area chooses to verify a deductible expense and the expense cannot be verified within 30 days of the date of application, the eligibility and benefit level shall be determined without a deduction for the unverified expense.
Verification at Recertification.
At recertification the local department shall verify:
A change in income if the source has changed or the amount has changed by more than $50;
Previously unreported medical expenses;
Actual utility expenses and total recurring medical expenses that have changed by more than $50;
A change in the:
Legal obligation to pay child support;
Obligated amount of child support received; or
Amount of legally obligated child support a household member pays;
Newly obtained Social Security numbers;
Hours worked for individuals subject to the work requirement for able-bodied adults without dependents as described in Regulation .23 of this chapter; and
Any other change if the information provided is questionable as described in Â§G of this regulation, incomplete, or outdated.
Unless a change is questionable as described in Â§G of this regulation, incomplete, or outdated, at recertification the local department may not verify:
Income, if the:
Source has not changed; and
Amount is unchanged or the amount has changed by $50 or less; or
Total medical expenses or actual utility expenses that:
Are unchanged; or
Have changed by $50 or less.
Verification of Changes Reported during a Certification Period.
Except as described in Â§F(2) of this regulation, changes reported during the certification period are subject to the same verification procedures that apply at initial application.
Unless a change is questionable as described in Â§G of this regulation, incomplete, or outdated, the local department may not verify:
Income, if the:
Source has not changed; and
Amount is unchanged or the amount has changed by $50 or less; or
Total medical expenses or actual utility expenses that:
Are unchanged; or
Have changed by $50 or less.
Questionable Information. A factor of eligibility is questionable when information provided by the household is inconsistent with:
Statements made by the applicant;
Information on the application or on a previous application; or
Information received by the local department.
Documentary Evidence.
A household may supply documentary evidence:
In person;
Through the mail;
By facsimile or other electronic device; or
Through an authorized representative.
The local department:
Shall accept any reasonable documentary evidence provided by the individual;
Shall be primarily concerned with how adequately the verification proves the statements on the application; and
May not require the individual to present verification in person at the local department.
An individual who is not exempt for a reason described in Â§B of this regulation is not eligible to participate if the individual:
Refuses, at the time of application and every 12 months after that, to be registered for work;
Refuses without good cause to:
Participate in an employment and training program to which the individual is assigned,
Accept an offer of suitable employment at a site or plant not subject to a strike or lockout at the time of the refusal,
Provide the local department or employment training program with sufficient information about employment status or availability for work; or
Voluntarily and without good cause:
Quits a job, as described in Regulation .24A(1) of this chapter, or
Reduces work hours as described in Regulation .24A(2) of this chapter.
A household member is exempt from the requirement to register for work if the member is:
Younger than 16 years old;
16 or 17 years old and neither the head of household as described in Regulation .13 of this chapter nor attending school or enrolled in an employment training program on at least a half-time basis;
60 years old or older;
Verified to be physically or mentally unfit for employment;
Complying with any work requirement under the Social Security Act, including Work Opportunities, and employment and training;
Responsible for the care of a child younger than 6 years old or an incapacitated individual;
Receiving or has applied for unemployment compensation and required to register for work;
A regular participant in a drug addiction or alcoholic treatment program;
Employed at least 30 hours per week or receiving earnings equal to the federal minimum hourly wage multiplied by 30; or
Enrolled in any school, training program, or institution of higher education on at least a half-time basis.

An individual shall register for work if, during the certification period, the individual loses exempt status because of a change in circumstances that the individual is required to report to the local department.

section.heading: Failure to Comply with Work Requirements.

para.text: If the local department determines that an individual has refused or failed without good cause to comply with the work requirements or employment and training program requirements, the individual is ineligible to participate in the Program for the following time periods:
After the first violation, the later of:
1 month, or
The date the individual complies with the work requirements;
After the second violation, the later of:
3 months, or
The date the individual complies with the work requirements; and
After the third or subsequent violation, the later of:
6 months, or
The date the individual complies with the work requirements.
If the individual moves to another household, the individual remains ineligible.
Conciliation Period for Failure to Comply with an Employment and Training Program Requirement.
The local department shall begin a conciliation period the day after the local department learns of the noncompliance.
The conciliation shall continue for a period not to exceed 30 calendar days.
The purpose of the conciliation effort is to:
Determine the reason the individual did not comply with the employment and training program requirement; and
Provide the noncomplying individual the opportunity to comply before the issuance of a notice of adverse action.

Within the conciliation period, the local department shall, at a minimum, contact the noncomplying household member to determine the reasons for noncompliance and determine if good cause exists as described in Â§G of this regulation.

Notice of Adverse Action. Within 10 days of the local department determining that an individual has not complied without good cause with a work requirement other than FSP employment and training program requirements, the local department shall provide a notice of adverse action containing the following:
The particular act of noncompliance committed;
The proposed disqualification period;
A statement that the individual may reapply at the end of the disqualification period; and
A description of the action the individual may take to avoid the disqualification.
Ending a Disqualification.

Following the end of the disqualification period for noncompliance with the work requirements or employment and training program requirements, participation may be resumed if the individual or household applies again and is determined eligible.

Eligibility may be reestablished during a disqualification period if the individual who caused the disqualification becomes exempt from work registration under the provisions of Regulation .21B(1)â(4), (6), and (8)â(10) of this chapter.
Suitable Employment.
Employment is considered suitable unless:
The wage offered is less than the federal minimum wage;
The employment is on a piece rate basis and the average hourly pay rate can reasonably be expected to be less than the federal minimum wage;
There are conditions of employment which require joining, resigning from, or refraining from joining any legitimate labor organization; or
The work offered is at a site subject to a strike or lockout unless the strike has been enjoined under Â§208 of the Taft-Hartley Act, or Â§10 of the Railway Labor Act.
Employment is considered unsuitable if the individual involved can demonstrate, or the local department becomes aware, that the:
Degree of risk to health and safety is unreasonable;
Individual is physically or mentally unfit to perform the work as documented by medical evidence or by reliable information from other sources;
Employment offered within the first 30 days of employment registration is not in the individual's major field of experience;
Working hours or routine of the employment interferes with the individual's religious observances, convictions, or beliefs; or
Distance from the individual's home to the place of employment is unreasonable considering the expected wage and time and cost of commuting.
A commuting time of 2 hours or more per day or the lack of private or public transportation renders a job unsuitable under Â§F(2)(e) of the regulation.
Determining Good Cause.
The local department shall determine if an individual had good cause for failing to comply with the work requirements, employment and training program, and voluntary quit requirements.
In determining good cause, the local department shall consider the facts and circumstances described by the individual and employer involved.
The local department may base a good cause determination on factors such as:
Illness of the individual involved or another individual in the household requiring the presence of the individual involved;
A household emergency;
The unavailability of transportation; or
The lack of child care for a child or children who are 6 years old or older but younger than 12 years old.
An individual shall be treated as though the individual failed to comply with the food stamp work requirements if the individual:
Is exempt from work requirements in accordance with Regulation .21B(5) or (7) of this chapter because the individual is subject to the TCA or Unemployment Compensation work requirements; and
Fails to comply with the TCA or Unemployment Compensation work requirements.

Unless an administrative hearing is requested and the individual is subject to benefits pending appeal, the disqualification period as described in Â§A of this regulation begins with the first month following the expiration of the 10-day adverse action period.

section.heading: Work Requirement for Able-Bodied Adults Without Dependents.

para.text: Except as described in Â§Â§B(6) and (7) and G of this regulation, an individual may not participate in the Program as a member of a household if, during a 36-month period, the individual received Program benefits for at least 3 months as described in Â§F of this regulation, consecutive or not, during which the individual did not:
Work 20 hours or more per week averaged monthly;
For 20 hours or more per week, participate in and comply with:
A Welfare Innovation Act program;
A Trade Adjustment Assistance Act program; or
An employment and training program;
Combine work and participation in a work program as described in Â§A(2) of this regulation that totals 20 hours a week averaged monthly;
Participate and comply with the requirements of a workfare program under Â§20 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008, or a comparable program established by the State or local government; or
Qualify for an exemption under Â§B or C of this regulation.
An individual is exempt from the requirement as described in Â§A of this regulation if the individual is:
Younger than 18 years old, or 47 years old or older;
Physically or mentally unfit;
A parent or other household member residing with a dependent child 17 years old or younger;
Pregnant;
Exempt from work requirements as described in Regulation .21B of this chapter;
Residing in one of the local department areas that has a waiver of the applicability of Â§A of this regulation from the Secretary of the United States Department of Agriculture; or
Exempt from work requirements in accordance with 7 U.S.C. Â§2015(o)(6).
Subsequent Eligibility. An individual denied eligibility under Â§A of this regulation shall regain eligibility if, during a 30-day period, the individual:
Works 80 hours or more;
Participates in and complies with the requirements of a work program for 80 hours or more; or
Fulfills the requirements of Â§A(3) of this regulation.
Maintaining Eligibility. An individual who regains eligibility under Â§C of this regulation remains eligible as long as the individual meets the requirements of Â§A of this regulation.
Loss of Employment. An individual:

Who regains eligibility under Â§C of this regulation and who no longer meets the requirements under Â§A of this regulation remains eligible for a consecutive 3-month period as described in Â§F of this regulation, effective the date the individual first notifies the local department that the individual no longer meets the requirements of Â§A of this regulation; and
May not receive any benefits as described in Â§E(1) of this regulation for more than one 3-month period in a 36-month period.
A countable month is a month during which the individual receives a full month's allotment.
The provisions of Â§Â§AâF of this regulation are not applicable from April 1, 2009 until September 30, 2011, in accordance with the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.

section.heading: Voluntary Quit and Reduction of Work Effort.

para.text: Determining Voluntary Quit or Reduction of Work Effort.
The voluntary quit provision applies if:
The employment:
Involved 30 hours or more per week; or
Provided weekly earnings at least equivalent to the federal minimum wage multiplied by 30 hours;
The quit occurred within 30 days before the date of application or anytime thereafter; and
The quit was without good cause.
The reduction of work effort provision applies if:
Before the reduction the individual was employed 30 hours or more per week;
After the reduction, the individual had weekly earnings of less than the federal minimum wage multiplied by 30 hours;
The reduction occurred within the 30 days before the date of application or anytime thereafter; and
The reduction was voluntary and without good cause.
An employee of the federal or State government or a local government who is dismissed for participating in a strike against the employer is considered to have voluntarily quit without good cause.
Good cause for quitting employment includes good cause as described in Regulation .22G of this chapter and any of the following:
Discrimination by an employer based on age, race, sex, color, disability, religious belief, national origin, or political beliefs;
Work demands or conditions that make continued employment unreasonable;
New employment or enrollment at least half-time in a school, training, or education program that requires quitting the employment;
A move to another place caused by another household member's new employment or enrollment at least half-time in a school, training, or education program;
Resignation of an individual younger than 60 years old which is recognized by the employer as retirement;
Employment that is or becomes unsuitable as defined by Regulation .22F of this chapter;
Acceptance of new employment or training that does not materialize because of circumstances beyond the control of the household member;
A pattern of frequent change of employers, as in migrant or construction work;
Changes in employment that result from termination of a self-employment enterprise; or
Resigning from a job at the demand of the employer.
A household may retain countable resources up to $2,000 except as described in Â§B of this regulation and Regulation .12 of this chapter.
A household may retain countable resources up to $3,000 if the household includes a member who is:
60 years old or older; or
Disabled as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter.
The local department shall measure the household's countable resources against the maximum allowable amount to determine the household's eligibility.
Cash on hand; and
Money in a checking or savings account.

section.heading: Excluded Resources.
section.text: Resources are excluded except as described in Regulation .26 of this chapter.

section.heading: Vehicles.
section.text: The local department may not include the value of a vehicle in calculating resource eligibility as described in Regulation .25 of this chapter.

para.text: At the time of application, the local department shall ask if any household member, or ineligible or disqualified individual whose resources are considered available to the household, transferred resources within the 3-month period immediately preceding the date of application.

A household which has transferred resources for the purpose of qualifying or attempting to qualify for benefits is disqualified from participating in the Program as described in Â§F of this regulation if the resources are transferred:
In the 3-month period before application; or
After the household is determined eligible for benefits.
Imposition of a Disqualification Period.
If the household has an application pending at the time of discovery of the transfer, the local department shall:
Send a written notice of denial explaining the reason for and length of the disqualification; and
Begin the period of disqualification in the month of application.
If the household is participating in the Program at the time of discovery of the transfer, the local department shall:
Send a notice of adverse action explaining the reason for and length of the disqualification; and

Begin the period of disqualification effective with the allotment that would have been issued after the notice of adverse action period had expired, unless the household requested a fair hearing and continued benefits.
Eligibility for the Program may not be affected by the following exempted transfers:

Resources that would not otherwise affect eligibility such as resources consisting of excluded personal property or money that, when added to other non-exempt household resources, totaled less at the time of the transfer than the allowable resource limits;
Resources that are sold or traded at, or near, fair market value;
Resources which are transferred between members of the same household, including ineligible aliens or disqualified individuals whose resources are being considered available to the household; and
Resources that are transferred for reasons other than qualifying or attempting to qualify for benefits.

The local department shall base the length of the disqualification period on the amount by which non-exempt transferred resources, when added to other countable resources, exceeds the allowable resource limit.
The following chart shall be used to determine the period of disqualification:
The local department may not count resources of nonhousehold members as available to the household, but shall count resources of excluded members as available to the remaining household members.
"Income" means all income from any source excluding only the income types specified in Â§D of this regulation.
Earned income includes:
Wages, salaries, tips, and commissions;
Income from self-employment as described in Regulation .39 of this chapter;
Training allowances from recognized government programs; and

Payments under Title I of the Domestic Services Act of 1973, such as the Volunteer in Service to America (VISTA) program when the individual was not receiving food supplement or public assistance at the time of entry into the volunteer program.
Unearned income includes:
Federally funded assistance payments;
State-funded assistance payments;
Annuities, pensions, and retirement benefits;
Workers' or unemployment compensation;
Social Security benefits;
Foster care and subsidized guardianship payments only if the household chooses to include the foster care individual in the food supplement household;
Net rental property income when no household member is actively engaged in management of the property for 20 hours a week or more;
Support or alimony payments;
Payments from government programs, dividends, interest except as described in Â§D(18) of this regulation, royalties, or money payments from any source which is a gain or benefit to the household;
Money withdrawn or dividends due to a household from a trust fund;
Dividends that the household has the option to use or reinvest unless excluded in Â§D of this regulation;
Amounts of unearned income deducted from a federal or State means-tested public assistance benefit to repay a claim intentionally caused by a household;
Earned or unearned income of an individual disqualified from the household as described in Regulation .40B and C of this chapter; and
Income of a sponsor and sponsor's spouse as described in Regulation .09-1 of this chapter.
Excluded income includes:
Income diverted at or returned to the source to repay a prior overpayment received from the source except as described in Â§C(12) of this regulation;
Child support paid to a TCA recipient that is required to be transferred to the Department's Child Support Enforcement Administration;
In-kind contributions which have other than a cash value to the household;
Vendor or third-party payments paid directly to a third party and not available as income to the household;
Irregular, unanticipated:
Earned income not exceeding $30 in any quarter; or
Unearned income not exceeding $200 in any 6 month period;
Any loan;
Reimbursements for past or future expenses, other than normal living expenses, if they do not exceed actual expenses;
Money received and used for the care and maintenance of a third-party beneficiary who is not a household member;
Earned income of a member of the household who:
Is an elementary or secondary school student;
Is younger than 18 years old; and
Lives with a natural or adoptive parent or stepparent, or under the parental control of a household member other than a parent;
A nonrecurring lump sum payment;
Cash donations based on need from one or more private nonprofit charitable organizations;
Income specifically excluded by federal law as countable income for Program purposes;
Any federally funded energy assistance payment, including HUD utility reimbursements, except for payments provided under Title IV-A of the Social Security Act;
Income of an SSI recipient which has been determined necessary for the fulfillment of a plan for achieving self-support (PASS) which has been approved by the Social Security Administration;
Public assistance vendor payments provided for emergency or special assistance;
Educational assistance as described in Regulation .31 of this chapter;
The deduction for self-employment income permitted under Regulation .39 of this chapter;
Interest earned on a bank account; and
Military combat pay.

Educational assistance includes grants, scholarships, fellowships, educational loans on which payment is deferred, work study, veterans' benefits, and other opportunities which are awarded to a household member enrolled:
At a recognized institution of postsecondary education;
At a school for disabled individuals;
In a vocational education program;
In a vocational or technical school; or
In a program that provides for obtaining a secondary school diploma or the equivalent.
The local department may not include educational assistance in calculating a household's eligibility or benefit level.
Earned Income Deduction. The local department:
Shall allow a deduction from income in the amount of 20 percent of any gross earned income; and
