May not include in the calculation of the earned income deduction any earnings excluded under Regulation .39B of this chapter.
The local department shall allow a deduction from self-employment income as described in Regulation .39B of this chapter.
Medical expenses are counted only for individuals who are elderly or disabled as defined in Regulation .02B of this chapter. Medical expenses include:
Medical and dental care by a licensed practitioner;
Hospitalization or outpatient treatment, including payments by the household for a former member who received care in a hospital or nursing home while a member of the household;
Prescription drugs and over-the-counter medication approved by a licensed practitioner;
Home medical supplies, sick room supplies, and prescribed equipment;
Health and hospitalization insurance premiums for the cost of health care only;
Medicare premiums;
Cost-sharing or spend down expenses incurred by Medicaid recipients;
Dentures, hearing aids, and prosthetics;
Costs of seeing eye and hearing aid dogs;
Eyeglasses;
Reasonable costs of transportation and lodging for medical treatment; and
Costs for in-home aide care or attendants.
Except as described in Â§C of this regulation, the allowable medical expenses are calculated for a monthly cost amount by:
Averaging a one-time expense over the remaining months of the certification period;
Allowing the one-time expense for 1 month; or
Allowing a known continuing expense in each month of the certification period.
For households certified for 24 months that have a one-time medical expense incurred during the first 12 months, the local department shall give the household the option of:
Deducting the expense for 1 month;
Averaging the expense over the remainder of the first 12 months of the certification period; or
Averaging the expense over the remaining months of the certification period.

section.heading: Dependent Care Expenses.
section.text: The local department shall allow payments for the actual cost for the care of children or other dependents when necessary for a household member to:

para.text: Seek, accept, or continue employment;
Comply with the employment and training requirements as described in Regulation .21 of this chapter; or
Attend training or pursue education that is preparatory to employment.
A household member who has verification of having made legally obligated child support payments to or for an individual living outside the household is allowed a deduction.
To be entitled to the deduction, the household member shall:
Have a legal obligation to pay; and
Make payments.
The child support deduction includes:
Anticipated payments that the household member will pay during the certification period;
Third-party payments by the household on behalf of the nonhousehold member in accordance with a support order;
Legally obligated payments by the household to obtain health insurance for the child; and
Arrearages if the payments are anticipated to continue during the certification period.
Alimony payments to or for a nonhousehold member may not be included as a child support deduction.
The local department shall allow a deduction in the amount set forth in Schedule L in Regulation .45 of this chapter for a household which:
Is homeless; and
Incurs shelter costs.
A household receiving the homeless shelter allowance may not also receive a deduction for shelter costs.
Shelter costs are limited to the following:

Continuing charges for the shelter occupied by the household, which include rent or mortgage, condominium fees, association fees, or other continuing charges leading to or resulting from the ownership of the shelter, including interest paid on a mortgage;
Property taxes;
State and local assessments;
Premiums for insurance on the structure itself, but not the separate cost for insuring furniture or personal belongings; and
Utility costs, which include:
Heating,
Cooling,
Cooking fuel,
Electricity,
Water and sewerage charges,
Garbage and trash collection fees,
Telephone allowance as described Schedule I in Regulation .45 of this chapter,
Fees charged by a utility provider for initial installation of a utility, and
Well and septic tank system installation and maintenance.
The local department may not include as shelter costs:
The amount paid for a security deposit; or
Any amount considered as payment for meals.
Allowing Shelter Costs for a Home Temporarily Unoccupied.
The local department shall allow shelter costs for a home if temporarily not occupied by the household because of:
Illness;
Employment or training away from home; or
Abandonment caused by a natural disaster or casualty loss.
To include the costs of a home vacated by the household:
The household must intend to return to the home;
The current occupants of the home, if any, may not be claiming the shelter costs for Program purposes; and
The home may not be rented during the absence of the household.

The local department shall allow charges for repair of a home that was substantially damaged or destroyed due to a natural disaster such as a fire or flood but may not include charges for repair of the home that have been or will be reimbursed by private or public relief agencies, insurance companies, or another source.
Utilities are limited to the expenses described in Regulation .37A(5) of this chapter.
Utility Allowances.
Utility costs included in the utility allowances are listed in Regulation .37A(5) of this chapter.
Except as described in Â§Â§C and D of this regulation, an eligible household shall use one of two utility allowances as described in Â§B(3) and (4) of this regulation.
Standard Utility Allowance (SUA). An SUA as described in Schedule G of Regulation .45 of this chapter shall be used by a household that:
Is billed for heating or for the operation of an air conditioning system or room air conditioner separately from the rent or mortgage payment;
Resides in public or private rental housing and:
Is billed by the landlord for actual costs of heating or cooling as determined by individual metering;
Is charged a flat rate for heating or cooling costs separately from the rent;
Is charged for excess usage of heating or cooling costs separately from the rent; or
Can prove that it actually pays utility bills of the type described in Â§B(3)(a) and (b)(i)â(iii) of this regulation that are in someone else's name; or
Receives direct or indirect assistance under the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981.
Limited Utility Allowance (LUA). An LUA as described in Schedule H of Regulation .45 of this chapter shall be used by a household that:
Is billed for two or more utilities as described in Regulation .37A(5) of this chapter separately from the rent or mortgage, but not for heat or cooling as described in Â§B(3) of this regulation; or
Resides in public or private rental housing and:
Is billed by the landlord for actual usage of the utilities that do not include heat or cooling as determined by individual metering;
Is charged a flat rate or for excess usage of utilities that do not include heat or cooling separately from the rent;
Is charged for excess usage of utilities that do not include heat or cooling separately from the rent; or
Can prove that it actually pays utility bills of the type described in Â§B(4)(a) and (b)(i)â(iii) of this regulation that are in someone else's name.
A household that lives with and shares utilities with other individuals or households is entitled to the SUA or LUA as described in Â§B(3) and (4) of this regulation.
A household that shares utilities between ineligible and eligible household members is entitled to the SUA or LUA as described in Â§B(3) and (4) of this regulation.

Except as described in Â§B(3)(c) of this regulation, if the cost of a principal heating or cooling source is included in the rent or mortgage payment, the household may be eligible only for the LUA regardless of whether the household uses and pays for supplemental heating equipment.

A household that incurs a separate telephone expense but is not entitled to claim a utility allowance shall use the mandatory telephone allowances in Schedule I in Regulation .45 of this chapter even if the actual expense is higher.
A household that incurs the cost of only one utility is eligible for the actual cost of the utility. The household shall verify the:
Cost of utility that is separate from any payment for rent or mortgage, including monthly charges by landlords for actual utility usage as determined by individual metering; and
Number of households that share the cost.
Energy Assistance.
The local department shall calculate if a household that receives indirect or vendor energy assistance from nonfederal funds is eligible for the SUA by:

Prorating the assistance over the season for which the payment is intended to cover, and determining if the household has incurred out-of-pocket heating expenses over the prorated amount in any month in the certification period;
Computing the proration by dividing the assistance amount by 5, which is the number of months, November 1âMarch 31, in the heating season; and
Determining if the household meets the out-of-pocket costs and the conditions of Â§E(1)(a) of this regulation.

If a household receives energy assistance that is authorized by federal law and administered by the Department's Maryland Energy Assistance Program (MEAP), to determine the household's eligibility for the SUA, the local department:
Need not prorate the MEAP assistance to determine out-of-pocket costs; and
Shall deem the full amount of the MEAP payment as an out-of-pocket expense.
A household shall report the receipt of all income, including indirect vendor payments, as the time of certification and recertification.
An expense covered by an excluded vendor payment is not deductible except for an energy assistance vendor payment administered by MEAP.
Calculation. The local department shall:
Annualize self-employment income that represents a household's annual income even if the income is received within a short period of time or the household receives income from another source;

Calculate self-employment income based on anticipated earnings if the averaged annualized amount does not reflect the household's actual circumstance because the household has experienced a substantial increase or decrease in business;
Average self-employment income that is meant to meet the household's needs for only a part of the year over the period of time the income is intended to cover; or
Average the income of a business that has been in existence for less than a year over the period of time the business has been in operation.

Deduction. The local department shall allow a deduction of 30 percent of the gross receipts of self-employment income as the cost of producing income, with the exception of the self-employment of farmers as described in Â§C of this regulation.
Self-Employed Farmers.
If the cost of producing self-employment income exceeds the income derived from a self-employment farming enterprise, the losses shall be offset against any other countable income.
To be considered a self-employed farmer, the farmer shall receive or anticipate receiving annual gross proceeds of $1,000 or more from the farming enterprise.

section.heading: Income and Resources of an Ineligible Household Member.

para.text: The local department shall count the countable income and resources of an individual who resides with the household but has been excluded from the household because the individual is:
An ineligible immigrant as described in Regulation .04B(1) of this chapter;
Without a Social Security number and has not applied for one as described in Regulation .11 of this chapter;
An able-bodied adult without dependents as described in Regulation .04B(4) of this chapter; or
Disqualified from the Program as described in Regulation .04B(2)(b)â(d) of this chapter after receiving notice.

The local department shall count the entire amount of countable income and resources of the ineligible individual excluded from the household as described in Â§A(4) of this regulation when calculating the total countable income and resources for the household.
Prorated Share.

The local department shall count the entire countable resources and the prorated share of the income of the ineligible individual in Â§A(1)â(3) of this regulation when calculating the total countable income and resources of the household.
The prorated share is calculated by subtracting the allowable exclusions and dividing the ineligible individual's remaining income evenly among household members, including the ineligible individual.
The prorated share is added to each member's countable income.
The prorated deduction is calculated as follows:
The 20 percent earned income deduction is applied to the prorated share of the excluded individual's earned income;
The share of the household's allowable shelter and dependent care expenses that are paid by or billed to the excluded individual is divided evenly among household members; and
The amount of each member's share is counted toward the shelter and dependent care expenses of the household.
The local department may not count the ineligible individual when determining:
Household size for the benefit level;
Household size for the income eligibility standard; or
Resource eligibility limit.
Treatment of Income and Resources of Nonhousehold Members.
The local department may not count the income and resources of an individual who resides with the household as available to the household if the individual is:
An ineligible student as described in Regulation .10 of this chapter; or
A nonhousehold member as described in Regulation .03D of this chapter.
Cash payments from the nonhousehold member to the household are considered income to the household.

section.heading: Failure to Comply with Another Assistance Program's Requirements.

para.text: The local department may not increase a household's allotment during the period the household's benefits received under another means-tested federal, State, or local public assistance program have been reduced, suspended, or terminated due to the household's failure to comply with a requirement of the program that imposed the benefit decrease.
The local department shall adjust Program benefits when:

Eligible members are added to the FSP household, regardless of any prohibition from receiving benefits for the additional member under another federal, State, or local public assistance means-tested program; or
Changes are reported that are not related to a penalty imposed by another federal, State, or local means-tested public assistance program.
A household that includes an elderly or disabled member shall meet the net income eligibility standards for the Program in Schedule B of Regulation .45 of this chapter.
A household that does not include an elderly or disabled member shall meet both the gross and net income eligibility standards for the Program in Schedules A and B of Regulation .45 of this chapter.
Categorically eligible PA or SSI households, as defined in Regulation .12 of this chapter, are not subject to income eligibility standards.

section.heading: Calculation of Household Net Monthly Income.
section.text: The local department shall compute net monthly income in the following manner:

para.text: Compute gross monthly income;
Subtract from the gross self-employment income the amount allowed by Regulation .39B and C of this chapter;
Subtract an earned income deduction of 20 percent of gross monthly earned income;
Subtract a standard deduction in the amount stated in Schedule E of Regulation .45 of this chapter;

Subtract that portion of medical expenses as defined in Regulation .33 of this chapter in excess of $35 per month incurred by a household member who is elderly or disabled as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter;
Subtract payments for the actual cost paid by the household to someone outside the household for the care of a child or other dependent as described in Regulation .34 of this chapter;
Subtract payments for child support for an individual living outside the home as set forth in Regulation .35 of this chapter;
Subtract a homeless shelter allowance as described in Regulation .36 of this chapter for homeless households in the amount stated in Schedule J in Regulation .45 of this chapter; and
Subtract any excess shelter cost as follows:

Excess shelter cost is calculated as the amount of the shelter cost, as described in Regulation .37 of this chapter, which exceeds 50 percent of the amount of income remaining after the deductions in Â§Â§AâH of this regulation are allowed,
Subtract the excess shelter cost not to exceed the maximum in Schedule F of Regulation .45 of this chapter, and
If the household contains an elderly or disabled member as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter, the total amount of the excess shelter cost is subtracted.

The household's monthly allotment shall equal the thrifty food plan for the household's size reduced by 30 percent of the household's net monthly income as calculated in Regulation .43 of this chapter.
Calculation. The local department shall:
Round up the product of 30 percent times the household's net income to the next whole dollar if it ends in 1 through 99 cents; and
Round up to $2, $4, or $6, respectively, if an allotment of $1, $3, or $5 results.
Prorating Benefits.
The local department shall prorate benefits for an initial month from the day the calculation is required to begin according to Regulation .14I or .18B and C of this chapter, to the end of the month.
A household applying on the 31st of a month shall be treated as though it applied on the 30th of the month.
The following formula may be used to calculate the initial monthly allotment:
I = F ((31-D)/30) where: I is the initial allotment, F is the full month allotment, and D is the date set by Â§C of this regulation.
If the calculation of the initial monthly allotment yields an allotment of less than $10 for the household, a benefit may not be issued for the initial month.

Except during an initial month, all eligible one and two member households shall receive a minimum monthly allotment of $16, and all eligible households with three or more members that are entitled to $1, $3, or $5 allotments shall receive allotments of $2, $4, or $6, respectively.

Other than households described in Â§F of this regulation, an eligible household with three or more members, which is not entitled to benefits except for the proration requirements of Â§C of this regulation and the provision precluding issuance of less than $10 in an initial month in accordance with Â§D of this regulation, the local department shall deny the household's application because its net income exceeds the level at which benefits are issued.

A household that files a joint public assistance-FSP application and is categorically eligible in accordance with Regulation .12 of this chapter after being denied non-PA benefits shall have its benefits for the initial month prorated from the date from which the public assistance is payable or the date of the original FSP application, whichever is later.

section.heading: Certification Actions and Certification Period Length.

para.text: Certification Period.
The local department shall:
Certify an eligible household for a definite period of time; and
Assign the longest certification period possible, based on the household's circumstances.
The first month of the certification period is the first month for which the household is eligible to participate.
A certification period:
May not exceed 12 months except as described in Â§A(3)(d) of this regulation;
Shall be 4 months or more for:
Homeless households; and
Migrant and seasonal farm worker households;
May not exceed 6 months unless the local department has contact with the household every 6 months and receives a report of changes in circumstances; and
May be up to 24 months if:
All adult household members are elderly or disabled as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter and have no earned income; and
The local department has at least one contact with the certified household every 12 months.
The local department may assign 1-month or 2-month certification periods when it appears likely that the household will become ineligible in the near future.
The local department shall issue a notice of eligibility to an eligible household, as described in Regulation .16A of this chapter.
The local department shall arrange for issuance of an EBT card to an eligible household.
Shortening a Certification Period. The local department may not:
End a household's certification period earlier than its assigned termination date, unless:
The local department receives information that the household has become ineligible;
The household has not complied with the requirements of Regulation .49G of this chapter;
The household receives transitional benefits as described in Regulation .49H of this chapter; or
The household applies for and is approved for another program and the certification period is shortened to align the eligibility periods of all programs; and
Use the notice of expiration as described in Regulation .52C of this chapter to shorten a certification period.
Shortening a Certification Period. The local department may not:
End a householdâs certification period earlier than its assigned termination date, unless:
The local department receives information that the household has become ineligible; or
The household has not complied with the requirements of Regulation 49G of this chapter,
The household becomes subject to simplified reporting requirements as described in Regulation .47B of this chapter during an established certification period with more than 6 months remaining;
The household receives transitional benefits as described in Regulation .49H of this chapter; or
The household applies for and is approved for another program and the certification period is shortened to align the eligibility periods of all programs; and
Use the notice of expiration as described in Regulation .52C of this chapter to shorten a certification period.
Lengthening a Certification Period.

Except as described in Â§F(3) of this regulation, the local department may lengthen a household's certification period once it is established, as long as the total months of the certification period do not exceed:
24 months for a household in which all adult members are elderly or disabled as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter and who have no earned income; or
12 months for any other household.
The local department shall advise the household with a notice of eligibility as described in Regulation .16 of this chapter if the local department lengthens the certification period.
The local department may extend the household's certification period to the end of a transitional benefit period established in accordance with Regulation .49H of this chapter.

Except as described in Â§C of this regulation, a household is required to report only when the household's total gross monthly income exceeds 130 percent of the federal poverty rate as described in Regulation .45, Schedule A, of this chapter for the household size at certification.
The local department shall act on any change reported to the local department by:
The household by way of a personal visit, by telephone, in writing, through SAIL, or by facsimile or other electronic device;
An individual in the community;
Another State agency such as a quality control or an investigative unit;
An electronic match; or
An out-of-State agency.
An individual subject to the work requirements as described in Regulation .23 of this chapter shall report a reduction of work hours below 20 hours per week.
Households shall report a required change not later than 10 days after the end of the calendar month in which the change occurred.

The household shall report any change listed in Regulation .47 of this chapter that occurs after the interview but before the date of the notice of eligibility, within 10 days of the date of the notice.
PA households that report changes in circumstances on a PA change form are considered to have reported the change for food stamp purposes.
When a household circumstance change is reported, the local department shall:
Document in the case file the change and the date the change is reported to the local department;
Act on the change as described in Â§Â§CâF of this regulation if the new circumstance is expected to continue at least 1 month beyond the month in which the change is reported;
Notify the household in writing of receipt of the change report and any resulting adjustments to the allotment;
Notify the household of any additional verification requirements resulting from the change;
Notify the household whenever changes in the PA grant will affect the allotment or certification period; and
Provide another change report form.
Increase in Benefits.

If the change is an addition of a new member who is not a member of another certified household, or a reduction by $50 or more in the household's gross monthly income, the local department shall issue:
Any increased benefits not later than the first allotment issued 10 days after the date the change was reported to the local department; or

A supplemental authorization for the amount of increase for that month if the report date is too late for the local department to effect an increase in the regular allotment in the month following the report.

Increased benefits due a household resulting from a reported change other than those specified in Â§B(1) of this regulation are effective not later than the first allotment issued 10 days after the date the change was reported.
Verification of Changes.
The local department shall obtain required verification before taking action on a change which increases benefits.
The household is allowed 10 days from the date the change is reported to provide verification.
If the household:
Provides verification within 10 days from the date the change is reported, the time frame for taking action as described in Â§B of this regulation begins on the date the change is reported; or

Fails to provide verification within 10 days from the date the change is reported, the time frame for taking action as described in Â§B of this regulation begins on the date the verification is provided.
The local department shall terminate benefits following the issuance of a notice of adverse action if the household refuses to cooperate in providing verification of the change.
If the local department fails to issue the increased benefits within the time limits provided in Â§Â§B and C of this regulation, it shall restore the benefits lost to the household.
Decreases in Benefits. If the household's benefit level decreases or the household becomes ineligible as a result of a reported change, the local department shall:
Issue a notice of adverse action within 10 days of the date the change was reported;

Make the decrease or termination effective not later than the regular allotment for the month following the month in which the notice period expired, unless the household requested a fair hearing and continuation of benefits; and
Obtain required verification before recertification.
Unclear Information.

When the local department receives information about a change in a household's circumstances during the certification period and cannot readily determine the effect of the change on the household's benefit amount, the local department shall issue a written request for contact that:
Clearly advises the household of the verification it must provide or the action it must take to clarify its circumstances;
Provides the household with at least 10 days to respond and to clarify its circumstances; and
States the consequences if the household fails to respond to the request for contact.
The local department shall issue a notice of adverse action as described in Regulation .51 of this chapter if the household:
Does not respond to the request for contact; or
Responds to the request for contact and refuses to provide sufficient information to clarify its circumstances.
If the household responds to the request for contact and provides sufficient information, the local department shall act on any change as described in Â§Â§AâF of this regulation.
Transitional FSP Benefits.

Except as described in Â§H(4) and (5) of this regulation, after the termination of a Temporary Cash Assistance (TCA) benefit the local department shall provide transitional FSP benefits for 5 months after the date on which the TCA benefit was terminated.

Amount of the Benefit. During the transitional benefit period, a household shall receive an amount of Program benefits equal to the allotment received in the month immediately before the date on which the TCA benefit was terminated, adjusted for the change in household income as a result of the loss of the TCA benefit.
Continued Eligibility after the Transitional Benefit Period.
To continue to receive Program benefits beyond the transitional benefit period the household shall cooperate in a recertification of eligibility as described in Regulation .52 of this chapter.
The local department may initiate a new certification period for the household receiving transitional benefits regardless of whether the prior certification period has expired.
A household may not receive transitional benefits as described in Â§H(1) and (2) of this regulation if the household:
Did not receive a TCA benefit for at least 1 month prior to the month in which the TCA benefit ended; or
Lost TCA or Program eligibility because of:
Failure to comply with a TCA eligibility requirement, as described in COMAR 07.03.03.19;
Failure to comply with work requirements as described in Regulations .21â.24 of this chapter;
Disqualification for an intentional program violation as described in Regulation .56 of this chapter;
Status as an individual fleeing to avoid prosecution, custody, or confinement after conviction for a crime, or attempt to commit a crime, that is a felony, for the period the individual is fleeing;
Ineligible immigrant status as described in Regulation .09 of this chapter;
A transfer of assets as described in Regulation .29 of this chapter; or
The household's move out of the State.
Application for Recertification.
During the transitional benefit period the household may apply for recertification at any time.
If a household applies for recertification as described in Â§H(5)(a) of this regulation, the local department shall determine benefits for subsequent months without regard to Â§H of this regulation.
The transitional benefit period shall end if:
A household member applies for Program benefits in another household during the transitional benefit period; or
The household reapplies for and is found eligible for TCA during the transitional benefit period.

If the local department discovers during the certification period that the household failed to report a required change, and, as a result the household received benefits for which it was not entitled, the local department shall reduce or terminate the allotment after sending the notice of adverse action.
The local department shall establish a claim against the household if the household received benefits to which it was not entitled as specified in Regulation .54 of this chapter.
The local department may not establish a claim against a household for not reporting a change not required to be reported.
Definitions.
In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Timely" means that the notice is sent at least 10 calendar days before the action is taken.
"Adequate" means that the notice includes:
The action to be taken;
The reason for the action;
A notice of the household's right to and the method for requesting a fair hearing; and
The availability of any free legal services.
Timely and Adequate Notice.
Before taking any action to reduce or terminate a household's benefits within the certification period, the local department shall give timely and adequate notice.
The local department may send an adequate notice not later than the date the household receives or would have received its allotment if the:
Household reports in writing information which results in reduction or termination of benefits; and
Local department can determine the household's allotment or ineligibility solely upon the household's written information.

When an EBT system error occurs during the redemption process which results in an out-of-balance settlement condition, the Department shall send adequate notice not later than the date of the action to adjust the account.
Request for a Fair Hearing and Continuation of Benefits.

If the household requests a fair hearing within 10 days of the notice of intended action as described in Â§B of this regulation and does not specifically waive continuation of benefits, the local department:
May not take the proposed adverse action; and
Shall continue the allotment at the same level pending the hearing decision but not beyond the end of the certification period.
A fair hearing request is effective if it is received in the local department as specified in COMAR 07.01.04.03F.

EBT Adjustments. If there are no benefits or insufficient benefits remaining in the household's account, the Department shall make the adjustment from only the next month's benefits regardless of whether this satisfies the full adjustment amount.
An individual notice of adverse action may not be provided to a household when:
The Department initiates a mass change that affects the entire Program caseload or a significant portion of the caseload;
The local department determines that all members of a household have died;
The local department determines that the household has moved from the local department area;
The benefit returns to its original level when restoration of lost benefits has been completed and the household was previously notified in writing of the date the increased allotment would end;
The household was notified at certification that its benefits would vary from month to month;
The household made a joint PA-FSP application and has been receiving Program benefits, and was notified at certification that Program benefits would be reduced upon approval of the PA application;
A household member is disqualified for intentional program violation, or the benefits of the remaining household members are reduced or terminated;

A household certified on an expedited basis fails to provide postponed verification after the local department provided written notice that verification was necessary for benefits to continue beyond the month of application;

The local department converts an allotment from cash and Program benefit repayment to allotment reduction as a result of the household's failure to make agreed upon payments as specified in Regulation .55 of this chapter;

The local department terminates the eligibility of a resident of a drug or alcoholic treatment center or group living arrangement because the facility either lost its certification from the State or had its status as an authorized representative food retailer suspended by the United States Department of Agriculture, Food and Nutrition Service; or
The household voluntarily requests, in writing or in the presence of a caseworker, that its participation be terminated.
A household may not participate beyond the expiration of the assigned certification period as described in Regulation .46 of this chapter without a determination of eligibility for a new period.

The local department shall provide the household with a notice of expiration of its certification period at least 1 day before the last month of the household's certification period but not earlier than the next to last month of the certification period except that:
A household certified for 2 months or less shall be provided the notice of expiration at the time of certification; and
The local department need not send a separate notice of expiration to a PA household if its Program recertification coincides with its PA redetermination.
The notice of expiration shall include the:
Date the current certification period ends;
Date by which the household shall file an application in order to receive uninterrupted benefits;
Household's right to file an application and the right to file the application by mail or through an authorized representative;
Telephone number and address of the local department and the name of an individual to contact for additional information;
Consequences of failure to comply with the notice of expiration;
Right to a fair hearing;
Right of a household consisting of SSI applicants or recipients to apply for recertification at an office of the Social Security Administration;
Notification to the household that to receive uninterrupted benefits the household shall:
Appear for any interview scheduled on or after the date the application is timely filed, and
Complete the processing steps of the interview and provide all required verification;

Notification, if applicable, of the number of days the household has for submitting missing verification after the agency informs the household of any further verification needed to receive uninterrupted benefits; and
Notification to the household that it is responsible for rescheduling any missed interviews.
Interview at Recertification.
As part of the recertification process, the local department shall:
Conduct an interview with a member of the household or its authorized representative at least once every 12 months for households certified for 12 months or less;
Waive the face-to-face interview for hardship situations as described in Regulation .15C of this chapter; and
Schedule any required interview so that the household has at least 10 days after the interview in which to provide verification before the certification period expires.
If a household misses its scheduled interview, the local department shall:
Send the household notice of the missed interview; and
Schedule a second interview if the household requests another interview.
Delays in Processing a Recertification.

If the household files a complete application for recertification by the date set by the local department, but the local department is unable to determine eligibility in time to provide uninterrupted benefits, the local department shall:
Provide benefits to an eligible household retroactive to the expiration of the previous certification period; and
Set a new certification period to begin with the expiration of the previous period.
If the household files an application within 30 days after the end of the certification period the:
Application is considered an application for recertification; and
Benefits are prorated as described in Regulation .44C of this chapter.
The local department shall restore lost benefits when:
An error is caused by the local department or by the Social Security Administration during joint processing; or
An administrative disqualification is subsequently reversed by a court decision.
The local department may not restore benefits for more than 12 months before the earlier of the date that the local department:
Receives a request for restoration from a household; or
Discovers or is notified that a loss of benefits has occurred.
The local department may not restore lost benefits for a household's:
Failure to file a timely recertification application;
Missing an interview; or
Otherwise not completing some aspect of the recertification process.
The local department shall restore benefits described in Â§A of this regulation even if the household is currently ineligible.
If the local department knows that the household is entitled to restoration of benefits, the local department shall automatically restore them without requiring further action by the household.
If the household was eligible but received an incorrect allotment, the loss of benefits may be only for those months in which the household participated.

If the loss was caused by incorrect delay, denial, or termination, the household's lost benefits shall be calculated beginning with the first month that the delay, denial, or termination occurred, but not for more than 12 months.
After the local department computes the date the loss initially occurred, the loss shall be calculated for each month after the date until either the:
Error is corrected; or
Household is found ineligible for any reason.
For each month affected by the loss, the local department shall:
Determine if the household was actually eligible;
Advise the household if the case record cannot document eligibility; and
Consider the household ineligible if the household cannot establish eligibility.
If the household received a smaller allotment than it was eligible to receive, the local department shall restore the difference between the actual and the correct allotment.

The local department shall offset restored benefits against any overissued benefits owed by the household, except that an initial allotment may not be reduced to offset claims even if the initial allotment is paid retroactively.

If the decision to disqualify is subsequently reversed, individuals disqualified for IPV are entitled to restoration of lost benefits during the months that they were disqualified. The amount to be restored is determined by including the disqualified member.
Method of Restoration.
The local department shall restore lost benefits by issuing an allotment equal to the amount of lost benefits.
Lost benefits may be issued in installments at the household's request.
The local department shall notify the household in writing of:
The favorable decision;
The amount of benefits to be restored;
Any offsetting that was done;
The method of restoration; and
The right to and the method for requesting a fair hearing.
The local department shall restore benefits to:
The household that contains a majority of the individuals who were household members at the time the loss occurred; or
If this household cannot be located, the household containing the head of the household at the time the loss occurred.
Disputed Benefits. If the household disagrees with the amount restored or the household requests restoration of lost benefits and the local department determines that no restoration is due:
The household has 90 days from the date the notice described in Â§N of this regulation is sent to request a fair hearing; and
If the fair hearing decision is favorable to the household, the local department shall restore benefits in accordance with the decision.

section.heading: Establishing a Claim for Overissued or Trafficked Benefits.

para.text: A recipient claim is an amount owed because of benefits that are:
Overpaid; or
Trafficked.

The local department shall establish and collect a claim in accordance with this regulation and Regulation .55 of this chapter, regardless of whether the local department meets the timeframe described in Â§I(1) of this regulation.
The following individuals are responsible for paying a claim:
Any individual who was an adult member of the household when the overpayment or trafficking occurred;
A sponsor of an immigrant household member if the sponsor was at fault; or
An individual connected to the household, such as an authorized representative, who actually trafficked or otherwise caused an overpayment.
The local department shall establish a claim against a household that has received more Program benefits than it was entitled to receive, except when the overissuance occurred because the:
Local department failed to ensure that the household:
Signed the application form,
Completed a current work registration form, or
Was certified in the correct local department area; or
Local department discovered the administrative error or inadvertent household error that caused the overissuance more than 12 months after the month of the occurrence.
The local department shall categorize claims as an:
Administrative error (AE);
Inadvertent household error (IHE); or
Intentional program violation (IPV).
Beginning with the date of the discovery of the overissuance, the local department shall include in its calculation of the amount of overissuance any issuance for the:
12 preceding months, in the case of an AE or an IHE; and
6 preceding years, in the case of an IPV.
Calculating the Amount of a Claim not Related to Trafficking.
The local department shall determine the correct allotment that the household was entitled to receive in each month in the periods described in Â§E of this regulation.
The overissued amount is the difference between the allotment the household received and the amount it would have received if information had been known and acted on in a timely manner.

The earned income deduction as set forth in Regulation .32 of this chapter is not applied when determining an overissuance due to the failure of a household to report earned income in a timely manner.
The first month of the overissuance:
Is the month:
In which the change in allotment would have been effective had it been reported; or
The local department should have effected a change in the allotment had it acted in a timely manner; and
May not be later than 2 months from the month in which the change in household circumstances occurred.
Trafficking Related Claims. A claim arising from a trafficking related offense is the value of the trafficked benefit as determined by:
The individual's admission;
Adjudication; or
The documentation that forms the basis for the trafficking determination.
The local department:
Shall establish a claim before the last day of the quarter following the quarter in which the:
Overpayment was discovered; or
Trafficking incident was determined as described in Â§G of this regulation; and
Need not establish a claim if the claim referral is $125 or less, unless:
The household is currently participating in the Program; or
The claim was established in a quality control review.

Claim Processing. The local department shall initiate collection on all established claims unless the claim is collected through an offset of benefits not yet restored as required in Regulation .53 of this chapter.
The local department shall initiate collection action by sending a demand letter to the household which contains language stating:
The amount owed;
The reason for the claim;
The period the claim covers;
Any offsetting that was done to reduce the claim;
The methods available to the household for repaying the claim;
The household's right to a fair hearing, if the household disagrees with the amount of the claim;
Notice of the availability of free legal representation;
The length of time the household has to respond to the letter by returning the signed copy;
That allotment reduction shall be initiated if a participating household fails to make restitution, and the methods to be used in allotment reduction;
That the local department may reduce the claim if the local department believes the household is not able to repay the claim;
That if the claim is not paid, the local department may:
Send the claim to other collection agencies; or
Refer the claim to the federal government for federal collection action;
How the claim was calculated; and
That if the claim becomes delinquent as described in Regulation .55E of this chapter, the household may be subject to additional claim processing fees.
Repayment Agreements. A repayment agreement for a claim shall:
Include due dates for repayment or time frames for the submission of payments; and

Specify that the household will be subject to involuntary collection action if the payment is not received by the due date and the claim becomes delinquent as described in Regulation .55E of this chapter.
The local department shall collect payment for a claim against a household as described in this regulation.
Lump Sum. The household may pay the claim in a lump sum that is a full or a partial payment of the claim made in:
Program benefits;
Cash; or
A combination of both.
Installments.
The household may choose monthly installments of a negotiated amount.
When a household is currently participating, the negotiated monthly amount for repayment may not be less than the amount specified in Â§D of this regulation.

Reduction in Allotment. Unless a payment schedule has been negotiated, the local department shall reduce the household's allotment to recover any amount of a claim not repaid through a lump sum as follows:
For an AE or IHE, an allotment reduction of the greater of $10 or 10 percent of the household's monthly allotment; or
For IPV, an allotment reduction of the greater of $20 or 20 percent of the household's monthly allotment.
Determining Delinquency.
A claim is considered delinquent if:
The claim has not been paid by the due date and a satisfactory payment arrangement has not been made; or
A payment agreement has been established and a scheduled payment has not been made by the due date.
A claim is not considered delinquent if:
Another claim for the same household is currently being paid through an installment agreement or allotment reduction;
The local department cannot determine delinquency status because collection is coordinated through the courts; or
The claim is awaiting fair hearing decision.

Treasury Offset Program. The local department or the Department of Budget and Management, Central Collection Unit, shall submit claims that are delinquent for 180 days or more and legally enforceable for collection from federal payments which include, but are not limited to:
Income tax refunds;
Federal salaries; or
Retirement benefits.
Local Department Action on Claims.
The local department shall:
Send a demand letter for repayment as described in Regulation .54K of this chapter; and
Reduce the allotment as described in Â§D of this regulation for a household that is participating in the Program.
If a household responds to the demand letter, but fails to comply with its repayment agreement according to Â§C of this regulation, the local department shall:
Send a notice that no payment or a lesser payment was received and that:
The household has a right to discuss renegotiation, and

Unless the household makes the overdue payments or contacts the local department, the allotment of a currently participating household against which a claim has been established may be reduced without an adverse action notice;
Initiate allotment reduction for currently participating households if there is no response to the notice; and
Take no further action if the household responds to the notice and makes a payment and states that it will continue to do so based on the existing agreement.
The local department shall repay to the household any overpaid claims by whatever method the local department considers appropriate, according to the household's circumstances.

The local department may choose other appropriate collection action, including referral to the Department of Budget and Management, Central Collection Unit when efforts by the local department have failed.
The local department may not require the household to liquidate its resources to make the repayment.
Terminating and Writing Off Claims.
Definitions. In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated:
"Terminated claim" means a claim in which all collection action has ceased.
"Written off claim" means the claim is no longer subject to continued federal or State collection and reporting requirements.
The local department shall terminate and write off a claim when:
The claim is invalid;
All adult household members die;
It is not cost effective to pursue the claim because:
The claim balance is $25 or less;
The claim has been delinquent for 90 days or more; and
There are no other claims against the household resulting in a total of greater than $25; or

The claim is delinquent for 3 years or more and the local department or the Department of Budget and Management, Central Collection Unit, does not plan to pursue the claim through the Treasury Offset Program as described in Â§F of this regulation.
The local department may terminate and write off a claim if the household cannot be located.
Changes in Household Composition.
The local department shall initiate collection action against any adult members of a household at the time an overissuance occurred.
In pursuing a claim, a local department may:
Pursue collection action against any household that has an adult member that received the overissuance;
Offset an amount of the claim against restored benefits owed to any household which contains an adult member of the original household at the time the overissuance occurred;
Use any of the appropriate methods of collecting payments listed in Â§Â§BâF of this regulation; and
Not collect more than the amount of the claim.

section.heading: Disqualification for Intentional Program Violation (IPV).
section.text: The local department shall investigate and refer any suspected cases of an IPV for an administrative disqualification hearing according to COMAR 07.03.10.

section.heading: Replacement and Use of Program Benefits.

para.text: The local department may replace Program benefits when food purchased with Program benefits has been destroyed in a verified household misfortune.
A household may use Program benefits to purchase eligible foods as described in Regulation .02B of this chapter or to enable the household to participate in a nonprofit cooperative or a meal service.
A household may not use Program benefits to buy:
Alcoholic beverages;
Tobacco or cigarettes;
Household supplies, soaps, and paper products;
Medicine or vitamins;
Any other non-food items;
Food that will be eaten in the store;
Hot foods that are ready to eat unless bought from an authorized homeless meal provider in accordance with Regulation .59 of this chapter; or
Pet food.
The retail food store may:
Request the purchaser to present identification when exchanging Program benefits for eligible food; and
Deny the exchange if the retail food store is not convinced the purchaser has the right to use the Program benefits.
The household may use benefits only for eligible food purchased at the time the benefits are presented.
A household may not use benefits to pay for any eligible food before receipt except when prior payment is for food purchased from a nonprofit cooperative or meal service.
Appeals.
The local department shall give written notice of the right to, and the procedures for, requesting and obtaining a fair hearing to each applicant, recipient, household, or authorized representative:
At the time of application; and
Whenever the local department notifies the applicant or recipient of any action which might deny, delay, suspend, reduce, or terminate benefits.
The appeal procedures are set forth in COMAR 07.01.04.

Complaints of Discrimination. An applicant, recipient, household, authorized representative, or individual acting on behalf of a client who believes the local department has discriminated on the basis of age, race, color, sex, disability, religion, national origin, retaliation, or political beliefs may file a written complaint in accordance with COMAR 07.01.03.08.
Approval and Authorization of Homeless Meal Providers.

To accept Program benefits in payment for meals, the homeless meal provider shall be approved by the local department and authorized by the United States Department of Agriculture, Food and Nutrition Service (FNS).
The local department shall approve in writing the establishment or shelter as a homeless meal provider upon evidence that the establishment or shelter serves meals to homeless individuals.

An approved homeless meal provider shall apply to the FNS local field office for authorization as a retail food store in order to accept Program benefits from homeless individuals. The requirements for approval are as follows:
Provide to the FNS the written approval received from the local department;
Be a public or private nonprofit organization as defined by the Internal Revenue Code;
Serve meals which include food purchased by the meal provider; and
Provide all data on the nature and scope of operations that may be requested by the FNS.
In this regulation, average cost is determined by averaging food costs over a period of up to 1 calendar month.
After receipt of the FNS authorization, the authorized homeless meal provider shall:
Request only voluntary use of Program benefits from a homeless FSP patron;
Establish that the FSP patron is homeless and thus has the right to purchase meals from an authorized homeless meal provider with Program benefits;
Limit the payment requested for the meal to not exceed the average cost of the food purchased by the homeless meal provider; and
Provide the option to a FSP patron to eat free or make a donation in cash or Program benefits if other patrons have the option of eating free or making a monetary donation.
The meal provider may accept voluntary payments by Program recipients in excess of average cost.
Exclusion of Costs. To determine the amount to be requested from the Program recipient, the meal provider may not consider:
The value of donated food from any source; or
Indirect costs, such as those incurred in the acquisition, storage, or preparation of the food used in meals.
A homeless meal provider may not act as an authorized representative for a homeless Program recipient.
The Maryland Senior Nutrition Assistance Program (MSNAP) is a 5-year demonstration project approved by the United States Department of Agriculture Food and Nutrition Service.
Household Composition. The definition of a household eligible to participate in this project is an individual who the Social Security Administration has determined is eligible for SSI, and:
Is 60 years old or older;
Is not currently receiving Food Supplement Program benefits;
Is living alone or if living with others is purchasing and preparing meals alone;
Has no earned income; and
Is a Maryland resident.
Application Process.
The Department shall:

Identify individuals eligible for the MSNAP through a match with Social Security Administration files that identify individuals who meet the MSNAP criteria, but who are not receiving Program benefits; and
Send an application to households that meet the criteria as described in Â§B of this regulation.

The local department shall process applications without an interview unless information is questionable as described in Regulation .20 G of this chapter, in which case a case manager shall complete a telephone interview.
Benefits begin the first day of the month in which the local department receives the MSNAP application.
An individual may not apply for MSNAP unless identified as described in Â§C(1)(a) of this regulation.
The expedited service provisions of Regulation .19 of this chapter do not apply to applicants for MSNAP.
Certification Period. The local department shall certify the household for 36 months.
Verification.
MSNAP income verification requirements will be fulfilled by using data verified under SSI regulations.
Unless information is questionable as described in Regulation .20G, the local department may not verify shelter costs.
Allotment Amount.
The allotment amount is one of two amounts based on the householdâs shelter cost, including the appropriate utility allowance, as described in Regulation .45G and H of this chapter.
The allotment for a household with a shelter cost of $505 or less is $80.
The allotment for a household with a shelter cost of $506 or greater is $125.
Reporting Changes. The local department:
May not require an individual who receives MSNAP benefits to report changes during the certification period; and
Shall take action on changes reported:
Through a data match with Social Security Administration files; or
By the household.
Opt Out Provision. MSNAP applicants may apply for the regular Food Supplement Program instead of the MSNAP.

Purpose. The Maryland Restaurant Meals Program provides elderly, disabled, and homeless SNAP recipients with the option to use their benefits to purchase hot, prepared foods from restaurants that have been approved by the Administration to participate in the program.
Definitions.
In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
âAdministrationâ means the Family Investment Administration of the Department of Human Services.
âFNSâ means the United States Department of Agriculture Food Nutrition Service.
âMOUâ means memorandum of understanding.
âProgramâ means the Restaurant Meals Program.
âRestaurantâ is defined as a private for-profit establishment where meals are sold and served to customers, including in store delis or delicatessens and food trucks.
The Restaurant Application Process.
A restaurant shall submit a complete Restaurant Meals Program application to the Administration.
A complete Program application shall include:
A completed MOU form; and
A completed U.S. Department of Agriculture Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program Application for Meal Services form.
Once an application is received by the Administration, the Administration shall review a restaurantâs application for completion and accuracy.
Incomplete Application.
The Administration will notify the applicant of all missing information by issuing a request for additional information within 30 days of application receipt.
If the applicant does not provide the requested information within 10 calendar days from the date of a request for information, the Administration shall deny the application.
Once the Administration determines an application is accurate and complete, it will forward the application to FNS for review and authorization.
If FNS does not authorize the restaurant to accept SNAP benefits, the Administration shall deny the application.
If FNS does authorize the restaurant to accept SNAP benefits:
The effective date of the MOU will be the date FNS provides its authorization for the restaurant;
The Administration shall insert the effective date on the MOU, which will then execute the MOU; and
The executed MOU will be mailed to the restaurant.
Participating restaurants:
Shall have an executed MOU with the Administration. One MOU may be executed for restaurants applying for multiple locations, provided that all restaurants are under the same ownership or structure;
Shall be authorized by FNS;
Shall offer meals at concessional prices by:

Serving meals that cost less than that which would be charged to customers not using SNAP benefits with a sales price at least 10 percent less than the sales price charged to customers who are not using SNAP benefits to pay for similar meals;
Serving meals already discounted for certain customers; or
Serving meals offered to all customers at advertised special or sale prices;
Shall be fully accessible to the disabled;
Shall have more than 50 percent of total sales in food;
May not be set exclusively for carry-out;
Shall collect SNAP benefits at the time of meal delivery;
May not be operating as a bar or tavern;
Shall post a sign notifying the public of the restaurantâs participation in the program;
May not charge, include, or otherwise collect a service gratuity for any food or meals sold to an individual participating in the program;
May not charge, include, or otherwise collect a sales or meals tax for any food or meal sold to an individual participating in the program; and
May not allow individuals participating in the program to purchase alcoholic beverages with SNAP benefits.
Household Eligibility.
An eligible household under this section may purchase hot, prepared foods at participating restaurants using SNAP benefits.
A household is eligible to participate in the RMP if the household is eligible to receive food supplement program benefits under State and federal law, and the household:
Lacks a fixed, regular, and adequate nighttime residence;
Includes only individuals who are:
60 years old or older; or
Designated disabled by a government entity;
Includes only an individual and the individual's spouse if the individual is:
60 years old or older; or
Designated disabled by a government entity; or
Includes only:
Individuals who are 60 years old or older; and
Individuals who are designated disabled by a government entity.
Determining Household Eligibility. The Administration shall review a household for program eligibility:
During the initial application for SNAP benefits; and
Each time the house is recertified or reporting a change.
Notification of Household Eligibility.
The Administration shall notify the household of its program eligibility.
The Administration shall notify the household if its program eligibility is discontinued and the reason for the discontinuation.
Fair Hearing Process.

The Administration shall provide notification of the right to and the procedures for requesting and obtaining a fair hearing to each applicant or recipient whenever the Administration notifies the applicant or recipient of any action which might deny, delay, suspend, reduce, or terminate assistance.
The appeal procedures are set forth in COMAR 07.01.04.
